#Text=Abba Jifar II
#Text=Moti Abba Jifar II was King of the Gibe Kingdom of Jimma ( r. 1878 – 1932 ) .
#Text=Reign
#Text=Abba Jifar II
#Text=a member of the Oromo people , [ 1 ] the son of Abba Gomol and Queen Gumiti .

#Text=He had several wives : Queen Limmiti , who was the daughter of the King of Limmu-Ennarea ; Queen Minjo , the daughter of the King of Kaffa ; and Queen Sapertiti , also from Limmu-Ennarea . [ 2 ]
#Text=During his reign there were Sufi saints who supported his rule .
#Text=One of them is Sadati Of Bure ( who later migrated to Illubabor ) .
#Text=In the 1880s , Abba Jifar II conquered a portion of the Kingdom of Janjero , which lay east of Jimma , along the Omo River , and incorporated it into his kingdom .
#Text=Due to the advice of his mother Queen Gumiti , to avoid the detriments of war , he agreed to submit to Menelik II , negus of Shewa in 1884 .

#Text=In 1886 , Abba Jifar II paid peace offerings consisting of " slaves ( including eunuchs ) , ivory , bamboo internodes filled with civet , jars of honey , locally made cloth , spears , shields ornamented with silver plates , and objects of wood ( including stools ) . " [ 3 ]

column1: #Text=Because of these " shrewd politics " ( Herbert S. Lewis ' words ) , which included providing military assistance to Menelik in conquering the neighboring kingdoms of Kullo ( 1889 ) , Walamo ( 1894 ) , and Kaffa ( 1897 ) , he was able to preserve the autonomy of Jimma until his death . [ 4 ]

column1: #Text=On the other hand , Alexander Bulatovich states that , when Jimma was annexed to Ethiopia , Emperor Menelik imprisoned Aba Jifar " for inspiring excessive enthusiasm in his own standing army and trying to entice Abyssinian soldiers to his own service " in Ankober for a year .
#Text=" When he was freed , " Bulatovich continues , " Aba Jefar again received the throne of Jimma from Menelik . " [ 5 ]
#Text=Queen Gumiti also advised him to expand the cultivation of coffee in his kingdom , which provided increased revenue for him and his subjects .
#Text=In January 1898 , as part of a Red Cross mission to southwestern Ethiopia , Bulatovich visited Jimma , and was the guest of Abba Jifar .
#Text=While in Jeren , Bulatovich treated the Queen Mother for " a little bronchitis " .
#Text=He left the following description of the king :
#Text=Aba Jefar is still a young man -- handsome , well-built , and somewhat in his prime .
#Text=He has a typical face : a straight thin nose ; bright , handsome eyes which shift suspiciously from side to side ; a thick black beard ; and black , short-cropped , curly hair .
#Text=His hands are graceful .
#Text=He wears large gold rings on all his fingers .
#Text=Dressed in a white shirt and trousers , he has draped over his shoulders the thinnest white shamma .
#Text=His feet are also very small and handsome , clad in leather sandals . [ 5 ]
#Text=Towards his later years , Abba Jifar II succumbed to senility .
#Text=His grandson Abba Jofir attempted to take control and re-assert Jimma 's independence .
#Text=However , Emperor Haile Selassie responded quickly and sent military forces against Abba Jofir .
#Text=The soldiers brought Abba Jofir back to Addis Ababa , where he was imprisoned . [ 6 ]
#Text=In 1930 , Haile Selassie removed an enfeebled Abba Jifar II from power and installed his son-in-law , Ras Desta Damtew , in his place .
#Text=Desta Damtew ruled as Governor ( Shum ) of Jimma , while Abba Jifar II was allowed to remain as King ( Negus ) as titular head .
#Text=When Abba Jifar II died in 1932 , the Kingdom of Jimma was officially ruled directly by the Emperor .
